Dear Harry?
Thanks for your letter of April 35 about the placement service.
•* presume that being away you did not receive my previous not© expressing
joy that MSB will shortly be in position to do a real placement job. You
will recall that I have been tHe one most stager to so© you get going in this,
for I feel that this is going to be one of tie very vital requirements for
the success of educational television, and I do hope that you will have
sufficient budget to do the scale of job that should be required. Incidentally,
it has occurred to k© that some msans should be found for giving in-service
training, and up-grading to seme of the people who come along who have good
experience records of one sort or another but little or no actual television
experience.
Our own efforts in this regard have been quite minor and incorporated
in our regular budget. We simply assigned one of our girls to pulling the
various letters, etc, we had received together, and she devised a form which
she circulated to past applicants to get a measurement of their present interest
and experience. It66 not an extensive file at all, and certainly nothing such
as there should be. She will get it bundled up and off to you as soon as she
can.
I was hopeful that Mr. Walker could get down to Washington so he
could see problems w© confront (and Ralph, of course, too) and thus b* in
better position to servo us. I presume that we shall continue to get letters,
people wi'l continue to drop in, etc., and we shall have to have some way of
taking care of them, and assuring proper follow-through. But all this can be
worked out as we go along.
Cordially,
Robert R„ Mullen
